[Scarpelli]: Present.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: That doesn't have to be a law.

[Scarpelli]: You don't have to disclose anything, any other news about what's legally can be said and what can't be said.

[Scarpelli]: You're all educated, very bright people to sit our student body down and look them in the eye and say, you're okay and this is why it's gonna happen.

[Scarpelli]: I'm not asking you to disclose any information about the perpetrator, the person who was injured.

[Scarpelli]: I'm not saying that.

[Scarpelli]: I appreciate taking this out of order.

[Scarpelli]: This has been a very emotional last 24 hours.

[Scarpelli]: It's been very intense and I wanted to make sure that if you allow me to give a small presentation that I prepared so I don't miss anything.

[Scarpelli]: Medford's in crisis.

[Scarpelli]: It's not a new crisis, but one that has started to spiral out of control and has just caught the attention of the outside world.

[Scarpelli]: Sadly, we had many years of warning given to us to prevent the latest incident.

[Scarpelli]: But as we see today, those warning signs were ignored by the very people that were entrusted to protect our kids by acting on our behalf.

[Scarpelli]: Most of you know my background as a former coach, teacher, and now Assistant Director of Recreation for Neighborhood Community.

[Scarpelli]: I wanna look at a few fundamentals to see where we missed out, where we made our mistakes.

[Scarpelli]: First thing that came to me is, are our kids safe?

[Scarpelli]: No, they're not.

[Scarpelli]: It's not the data that we need now, we now have the actual proof

[Scarpelli]: from our experiences.

[Scarpelli]: Are we doing all that we can to keep our kids safe so they can learn and grow successfully?

[Scarpelli]: No, the warning signs are there and we ignored it.

[Scarpelli]: Are we unified on this issue?

[Scarpelli]: Absolutely not.

[Scarpelli]: Sadly, some people take their responsibility serious while others do not.

[Scarpelli]: I question the personal motives

[Scarpelli]: of some to simply protect their income versus protecting people that got them elected or hired.

[Scarpelli]: There are outside groups currently bullying elected officials to exercise their views, which do not help to protect our kids.

[Scarpelli]: National organizations, national movements, while we're having crisis here in our own backyard.

[Scarpelli]: Is our division hurting our kids and the reputation of our city?

[Scarpelli]: Yes, that's evident.

[Scarpelli]: The division in this great community is tragic.

[Scarpelli]: If it continues, we'll just see the first of many situations that will bring our amazing city even further down.

[Scarpelli]: Now, two heads are better than one, and four heads are better than two.

[Scarpelli]: Unified, we will overcome together,

[Scarpelli]: divided we will continue the sad, turbulent ride to a much worse place.

[Scarpelli]: You know, last night I was accused of politicizing this issue.

[Scarpelli]: My knee-jerk reaction was quickly defended to the categorization of being looked at and politicizing this issue.

[Scarpelli]: Then I thought about it.

[Scarpelli]: Of course I'm politicizing this issue.

[Scarpelli]: because that's the only way, the only mechanism that we, our kids and the citizens have to make any changes to our system.

[Scarpelli]: We live in a political system that requires checks and balances to protect our citizens.

[Scarpelli]: So being attacked with this term makes no sense and showed me exactly how those that are guilty continue to deflect away from their own inaction, neglect and responsibilities.

[Scarpelli]: Well, we've learned that inaction equals action, meaning inaction enabled these outcomes, putting our kids in harm's way and making our parents petrified to send our kids to school.

[Scarpelli]: That's the atrocity that we are looking at today, right now.

[Scarpelli]: If anyone has been politicizing this issue, it's those that have been both enabling these outcomes and hiding from the consequences of their own inactions.

[Scarpelli]: We were elected by the people, for the people.

[Scarpelli]: It's time that we get to work for the people, especially our children.

[Scarpelli]: See, when we got elected by the people,

[Scarpelli]: It should not be measured by winning or losing.

[Scarpelli]: It should be measured by the impact that we make and promises that we keep.

[Scarpelli]: This is our opportunity that has presented itself to us today.

[Scarpelli]: The question was presented, what are we going to do about it?

[Scarpelli]: Here's what I propose to get us united, back on track and protect our kids the way that they require from us.

[Scarpelli]: First, I'm going to be asking the mayor to put together a team so we can put an implementation of safety that works with our teachers, our principals, our police department, so our kids feel safe when they go back on January 3rd.

[Scarpelli]: We want them to feel safe.

[Scarpelli]: Meetings, consultants,

[Scarpelli]: That's passed.

[Scarpelli]: We have true professionals in our building that we can work together over the next two weeks to make sure we have that plan in place.

[Scarpelli]: I'm sure of that.

[Scarpelli]: I have resolutions in place this evening that would ask the mayor to prepare an RFP to hire and train true security guards, four to five.

[Scarpelli]: Make sure that we have full staffing in the video room where our staff can watch a minute-to-minute action and who's going into the bathrooms, who's loitering in the hallways, to make sure our administration can see where these issues are happening and get

[Scarpelli]: the support there as soon as possible.

[Scarpelli]: Last night, I believe it was Tony Puccio who brought up a very simple resolution.

[Scarpelli]: We ask our parents today to do everything, to be involved.

[Scarpelli]: And he mentioned that.

[Scarpelli]: I thought that was a great idea.

[Scarpelli]: When I got home, I got a phone call from a former soccer captain.

[Scarpelli]: She went to school in Tulane, worked in Louisiana, and she sent me an article about

[Scarpelli]: a program they use in the schools in Louisiana where they were having issues and concerns like we're having today.

[Scarpelli]: It's called Dads in the Hall.

[Scarpelli]: Maybe to be correct, we'll call it Dads and Moms in the Hall.

[Scarpelli]: If we could put parents on a bus to go to a field trip to Plymouth Rock, then we could put parents in the school that want to assist our teachers to make sure they're just an extra eyes and ears as you walk the halls.

[Scarpelli]: So I thank you, Mr. Puccio, for bringing that forward.

[Scarpelli]: I'm going to ask the school committee to open up their meetings for public participation, where there's a dialogue like last evening.

[Scarpelli]: So if there's an issue with parents, students, or constituents, they have this forum to come and speak with a dialogue back and forth to make sure things are identified.

[Scarpelli]: The process that's in place right now, as some parents can tell you tonight, very daunting.

[Scarpelli]: to put it through, to ask to get approval, to read something, to write something up and making sure that what is going to be presented is approved is another form of censorship.

[Scarpelli]: If not, I'm gonna request this council to go back to the original request that Councilor Knight and I put forth as a ordinance change demanding that we put in place that format for the City School Committee so they have an avenue

[Scarpelli]: to have a voice and they can listen.

[Scarpelli]: So this has been a very intense last 24 hours.

[Scarpelli]: My daughter didn't go to school, nor did I believe close to 400 other students.

[Scarpelli]: The word back was that the police were there and they were present, but we also know that won't happen every single day for the rest of the year.

[Scarpelli]: So I implore our school committee to work together with the police department to move forward to making sure that there's a plan in place over the next few weeks so we have our children feeling safe.

[Scarpelli]: And that leaves me with one thing.

[Scarpelli]: I know that she's not here right now,

[Scarpelli]: But I want, I heard something last night from a very courageous young lady and I want to leave with something that she said that I take it.

[Scarpelli]: It was directed to me.

[Scarpelli]: It's direct to all of us.

[Scarpelli]: It was very simple to, as she said, step up a step down.

[Scarpelli]: We have a responsibility and I hope we hear it.

[Scarpelli]: We have a responsibility to make sure that we're giving the tools to our leaders in the school, our principals and assistant principals, to make sure that they can run the schools as efficient as they did when they led the middle schools or before this administration, when they were part of the resolutions.

[Scarpelli]: So let's unify this community.

[Scarpelli]: Let's unify our schools.

[Scarpelli]: and let's make Medford the city that it's always been, an amazing place to live, work, and raise their family.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Point of information if I can.

[Scarpelli]: The funding was there for the school system.

[Scarpelli]: I believe it was probably 80% of the funding that was cut for security over the last four years.

[Scarpelli]: So the funding was there and the school system cut that funding.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: trying to be restrained and understanding something very simple that I want to share with my fellow Councilors that gave their opinions.

[Scarpelli]: Agree to disagree.

[Scarpelli]: We've done that many times.

[Scarpelli]: These are our children.

[Scarpelli]: They're unsafe.

[Scarpelli]: They're scared.

[Scarpelli]: Our teachers are scared.

[Scarpelli]: To talk about money concerns and money issues should not be even a thought right now.

[Scarpelli]: The thought and the discussion of 30 years ago, five years ago, is an embarrassment to me for the fact that this is happening.

[Scarpelli]: This is happening right now.

[Scarpelli]: When I talk about unifying, I talk about what I said as a national agenda.

[Scarpelli]: We see and hear the direction that the school committee has gone on many different levels.

[Scarpelli]: And some school committees members have called me in the past and just didn't understand that they wouldn't fight if they didn't have their own voice, but to follow this national agenda.

[Scarpelli]: And as I'm seeing,

[Scarpelli]: the people that I looked at and trusted and admired, I'm seeing that they're taking not what's important today in our schools, not what's important, our children, not their safety, but to be in this council chamber yesterday and listen to some of these people that truly are aligned with people in this room.

[Scarpelli]: So these issues are concerning to the community to understand

[Scarpelli]: that we need to put that away, open our minds and be unified in the fact that the unification is needed for the safety of our children.

[Scarpelli]: Not what happened five years ago, not what happened 30 years ago, what's happening today.

[Scarpelli]: We're not gonna get the funding we need.

[Scarpelli]: We know that, but that's not gonna change.

[Scarpelli]: So bringing that up right now is really sad to me.

[Scarpelli]: That's just a buzzword and a check off.

[Scarpelli]: So I will tell you, we need movement now.

[Scarpelli]: We need our school committee, our superintendent to move now.

[Scarpelli]: I wanna see action now.

[Scarpelli]: Let's stop, let's hold school off for the next four days, three days.

[Scarpelli]: Let's bring our teachers into a room with our principals and let's find a solution right now.

[Scarpelli]: Many people I know are thinking of their home as an asset for retirement.

[Scarpelli]: As we all know the cost of living and the cost of health care in this area are tremendously expensive.

[Scarpelli]: Some have leveraged their homes values to offset the college education of the children.

[Scarpelli]: Others were hit with illness and sent them in a different direction in life and thus the need for this asset is paramount to living a normal life in the city.

[Scarpelli]: I know this from experience.

[Scarpelli]: Most of us are not real estate moguls looking to make a fast buck.

[Scarpelli]: We're citizens who have worked hard our whole lives in this community.

[Scarpelli]: dispositions of all items appearing on the city council agenda.

[Scarpelli]: All items of business appearing upon council agenda shall be taken up in the order their parents and fully openly debates the disposal of by vote of council previous to the consideration of any other item of business.

[Scarpelli]: No item of business shall be referred to committee except for the following reasons.

[Scarpelli]: for the study and the report of subsequent meeting, for the purpose of drafting an ordinance, and the event that open discussions may prove damaging to the character and reputation of a person or persons, all matters referred to the committee shall reappear on the council agenda for the meeting for four weeks following the referral, unless sooner presented by the committee chair or a majority not exceeding two weeks is voted by the council upon request of the committee chair.

[Scarpelli]: majority committee memberships.

[Scarpelli]: Any financial paper appearing on the council agenda for the first time shall be automatically laid on the table for one week when such action is requested by any member.

[Scarpelli]: Now you might've suspended the rules, but I want the community to realize you stifled me last time disrespectfully shutting down rule 21 because I made sense.

[Scarpelli]: What have we spent on for legal fees in the hundreds of thousands?

[Scarpelli]: What have we used in settlements?

[Scarpelli]: There are millions of dollars that we wasted because you put a cape on and thought that was your job, and that wasn't.

[Scarpelli]: And the courts, obviously now we're hearing it and we're seeing it.

[Scarpelli]: So I will be honest with you, again, it would have been nice to have some time to sit with the community and figure out, or at least all the council, because it seems like six people know what they're doing in the council, but there's one person sitting back saying, well, I had questions.

[Scarpelli]: I had things to offer.

[Scarpelli]: And when I came out and started sharing that on the council floor,

[Scarpelli]: I was pushed by asking me to put the amendment first, then I was asked to verify comments, and then when it started getting heavy and it started making sense, we sectioned 21-me.

[Scarpelli]: And now we get to tonight where I think we do need breathing room.

[Scarpelli]: We need another week to look at this, to look at this and ask some questions and make sure people, through the democracy, the process of democracy, that people ask these questions.

[Scarpelli]: And you can pat yourselves on the back all you want of this task force, and you came to this agreement.

[Scarpelli]: But to present all the information from this hardworking task force that was presented to the public on a Thursday or Friday, and then brought out for a vote tonight, is a disgrace.

[Scarpelli]: It's really, this isn't the way democracy works.

[Scarpelli]: And I know if you, deep down inside, I think all of you know it.

[Scarpelli]: So, Mr. President,

[Scarpelli]: I know that a lot of people do want to speak, and again, I'm just going to leave off with this.

[Scarpelli]: We had a mechanism in place that could have taken care of our children, our teachers, our parents, all these coaches and teachers that you're looking for.

[Scarpelli]: through free cash, which we had millions because of the process that was mismanagement of finances in our community for the last five years.

[Scarpelli]: And an abundance of that much money is just bringing it back to who deserves it, and that's the taxpayers.

[Scarpelli]: Remember, that's the taxpayers' money that weren't spent correctly.

[Scarpelli]: they can get their help and the support, but at the same time not affect a residential area that's.

[Scarpelli]: We then noticed that,

[Scarpelli]: We were informed that in this packet that we've now have $9 million added to that free cash to roughly $34 million.

[Scarpelli]: And I'm curious, when you went through this process, did the financial task force identify, did they know about that $9 million as it's going forward?

[Scarpelli]: Okay, so I know that my fellow councils, we have five money papers in front of us, and they, I believe, what was it you implemented?

[Scarpelli]: the rules to avoid Rule 21.

[Scarpelli]: I will do this with all the papers tonight, but as my right, I'm invoking state law under Chapter 43, Section 22, which reads, Section 22, any ordinance or order or resolution may be passed through all stages of legislation at one session, provided that no member of the Council objects thereto.

[Scarpelli]: If any member of the council objects, the measure shall be postponed for that meeting.

[Scarpelli]: So I'm going to vote that right for the fact that we're pushing things through and we're not getting the information, at least this council is not getting the information they want.

[Scarpelli]: And it's a tactic that's very silly that we're going to try to get information that was passed, that was information that was given to me.

[Scarpelli]: And I made sure that we reached out to the state legal department and they said, any budget paper,

[Scarpelli]: If this is invoked, our ordinance is invoked, then I can supersede that with the state ordinance until I, as one city council,

[Scarpelli]: who finds this process so faulty, and so smelling with the lack of transparency, that we're so confused of where this money is coming from,

[Scarpelli]: and I've used this many, many times.

[Scarpelli]: You're all very bright people.

[Scarpelli]: I'm not saying anybody's doing anything illegal.

[Scarpelli]: I'm telling you this is financial mismanagement.

[Scarpelli]: We asked for a $7.5 million override on the fare of our families and children.

[Scarpelli]: I wanted to propose a $5 million free cash proposal that eliminate that fare, then the community can look to see whether we need an override or not, which I wouldn't oppose.

[Scarpelli]: But instead, we required it.

[Scarpelli]: I was stifled.

[Scarpelli]: And then we moved to the next meeting, which was the budget meeting, and we had similar questions.

[Scarpelli]: Now we move to the next meeting, we come up with $9 million.

[Scarpelli]: We have $34 million in free cash, with an override still hanging out there.

[Scarpelli]: Are we still nervous about the kids in the schools?

[Scarpelli]: Well, I have the right to invoke this rule, and I do so, and I will do with all money papers tonight.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: I've been instructed by legal industry that this is a money paper that I can implement at my disposal, in my discretion, and I do so.

[Scarpelli]: So I question the chair, if you wanna stretch this out even longer,

[Scarpelli]: I am opposing rule 22.

[Scarpelli]: Yes, I have it in front of me.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you so much.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: The point of my resolution is very simple.

[Scarpelli]: This Councilman and I use the words transparency and accountability very often, and I do too.

[Scarpelli]: These words count.

[Scarpelli]: at the count only if we not only talk the talk, but we walk the walk.

[Scarpelli]: As this City Council is well aware, I submitted a letter to the Attorney General and the State Auditor's Office expressing my concerns over the way the City Council has used Rule 21 in Mass General Law, C-43, Section 22, unfairly and in a self-serving way to eliminate the discussion of resolutions that call for the expenditure of millions upon millions of dollars.

[Scarpelli]: When papers from the mayor were before the city council on June 7th, the council suspended the rules and approved the motion that the council rule 21 not be allowed to be invoked.

[Scarpelli]: Then on June 25th, my request to invoke Mass General Law C-43, section 22, which allows any one council to postpone consideration of a paper for one week was ruled out of order.

[Scarpelli]: At both of those meetings, my hope was that we could have an appropriate amount of time to discuss these significant issues and also receive input from our residents.

[Scarpelli]: When the council leadership ruled my request out of order, I had no choice but to bring this to the attention of the proper state offices to receive their input.

[Scarpelli]: The state auditor's office responded to me quickly.

[Scarpelli]: and reviewed my requests and explained first the requirements of the majority of the city council and the agreement of the mayor to move forward.

[Scarpelli]: So here's the simple part.

[Scarpelli]: If this council feels confident that its actions of those two meetings were correct, then your confidence in your actions can be reflected in your yes vote to allow this review.

[Scarpelli]: That would be true transparency and accountability.

[Scarpelli]: If however, you're not confident that the council's action were correct, you should still vote yes for this review because then we will have guidance from the state as opposed to an opinion bought and paid for by attorneys hired by the mayor.

[Scarpelli]: That would be true transparency and accountability.

[Scarpelli]: However, if you vote no on this resolution, it will show the residents of our city that this council uses the words transparency and accountability as a punchline that is empty and deceptive.

[Scarpelli]: Now is the time to stand up for what you say you believe in.

[Scarpelli]: let everyone know the only thing greater than your hollow words is your cowardice.

[Scarpelli]: So I will tell you, I will ask as a form of a motion that we vote to send this to be reviewed by the auditor, state auditor's office to look at our finances.

[Scarpelli]: Now, again, I'll say it publicly again.

[Scarpelli]: I have not one time mentioned

[Scarpelli]: that there is someone doing something illegal with the city's funds.

[Scarpelli]: Yes.

[Scarpelli]: So, I want the examination of our city finances, and I'll be meeting tomorrow with the Attorney General's office and talking about the legalities of the processes we have here.

[Scarpelli]: Any further discussion by members of the council?

[Scarpelli]: Mr. President, I just have one comment.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: Just to expand on what Councilor Callahan mentioned about the process and how everybody was here that night and they were so excited about the override and giving the voice to the people first time voting on it.

[Scarpelli]: If you remember the conversation and if you remember the dialogue that was set forth in my motions,

[Scarpelli]: was the fact that we had a financial task force that we didn't see or understand how they got to that situation.

[Scarpelli]: We didn't see how they showed us why we need an override, what got us to that override, and what are we gonna do in the next steps to make sure that we don't need another override the following year.

[Scarpelli]: These are the questions.

[Scarpelli]: This is a transparent process that we were asking for that evening.

[Scarpelli]: And of course people came up and voted for it.

[Scarpelli]: And of course they want to be told that we should go on to vote.

[Scarpelli]: Sure.

[Scarpelli]: But you're not listening to the people that are right in front of you.

[Scarpelli]: As many of those people that came up and said, we're for it, thank you so much.

[Scarpelli]: You have the same amount of people that are telling you right now.

[Scarpelli]: You're not listening to them.

[Scarpelli]: But you're not hearing them.

[Scarpelli]: So I find it a little disturbing that the process of silencing or discussing or transparency or accountability would have come out in those meetings and discussions

[Scarpelli]: when we had the opportunity before the votes came out and understood, okay, the financial task force met.

[Scarpelli]: no minutes, no understanding how they got to where they did, but we're gonna come out with a $7.5 million override, a $30 million debt exclusion, which by the way, you're gonna be shocked when the firefighters come knocking pretty soon, and the understanding that not just a week later, we find $9 million more in free cash.

[Scarpelli]: That alone, if that doesn't open your eyes and say, well, geez, Councilor Scarpelli, eliminate all the negative banter, eliminate one side or the other, geez, that's exactly what happened.

[Scarpelli]: And yeah, maybe we should look at that.

[Scarpelli]: Even though, Councilor Tseng said it, you just said it, people came to that podium.

[Scarpelli]: Of course they were in favor of it.

[Scarpelli]: But the problem was the people that had questions weren't listened to.

[Scarpelli]: That's a lack of transparency and accountability, my friend.

[Scarpelli]: This is the problem we have.

[Scarpelli]: This is why we're here.

[Scarpelli]: So you might be confused in the verbiage that I'm sending the auditor, but let me simplify it.

[Scarpelli]: I'm asking the auditor, with our vote,

[Scarpelli]: to look at our city's finances, period.

[Scarpelli]: We'll move forward with the Attorney General after I speak with them tomorrow.

[Scarpelli]: Maybe they have something to share.

[Scarpelli]: But this isn't a very difficult, you can make this a convoluted resolution and be very confusing just because you wanna sign it, but it's a very, to everybody, it's a very simple process.

[Scarpelli]: My resolution states that we ask the state auditor by a city council vote and then the mayor's approval

[Scarpelli]: to come in and look at the city's finances because I question the process of millions of dollars in free cash and the process of how we got to certain votes when it comes to a financial task force that didn't have minutes to explain to the public what's happened to this community financially, period.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Council President.

[Scarpelli]: If you'll allow me, over the past few years, I've heard many people talk about the legal claims or settlements or court judgments that have been paid by the city or school department for claims made against the city.

[Scarpelli]: the school department or employees of the city or the schools.

[Scarpelli]: Yet many of these claims and settlements that have been mentioned have never come before this council, either for an appropriation of money for payment or just to inform us about the claims.

[Scarpelli]: Going back to a time even before I was on the council, I know that the council had to approve the expenditures of any amount that was over $2,500.

[Scarpelli]: The purpose of this resolution is for the council to be made aware of the expenditures to settle or pay for various claims made against the city, the school, or any of our employees of the city or our schools.

[Scarpelli]: My motivation to bring this resolution forward is based on a very simple principle that I'm sure my colleagues can agree with.

[Scarpelli]: That is, expenditures of the city revenue is always a matter of accountability, transparency, and good government.

[Scarpelli]: People deserve to know where municipal dollars are being spent.

[Scarpelli]: With this in mind, I ask for the support of my colleagues on this resolution.

[Scarpelli]: Now, as we said tonight, I know that we mentioned just tonight, right?

[Scarpelli]: We said we need more funding, right?

[Scarpelli]: We need more funding.

[Scarpelli]: And we've seen over the last couple of months, we've seen a blatant financial mismanagement of our city's finances, as witnessed with the $9 million of free cash that was recently certified.

[Scarpelli]: The lack of new growth in our community over the past four years.

[Scarpelli]: Payments to outside councils that we still have yet to find what the true numbers are.

[Scarpelli]: And lastly, the settlements that mostly are unfunded by the city leadership.

[Scarpelli]: So this is very important because it's another aspect that week after week we're coming forward and that we're seeing mismanagement of our city funds.

[Scarpelli]: that the biggest issues we have is that when they do open the streets, not just, not your company, but we're seeing too many, too many jobs that are left half done, and it's creating more havoc when people leave.

[Scarpelli]: And I think the biggest piece is having a curb-to-curb process.

[Scarpelli]: That's something that, to me, as one councilor, is a non-negotiable.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you so much.

[Scarpelli]: And I very well put Councilor Callahan, but to further to expound on the free cash is the essential, the amount of money communities have over-budgeted.

[Scarpelli]: And according to the Mass General Department of Revenue, free cash represents the amount of community funds that are unrestricted and avail of appropriation.

[Scarpelli]: For example, the city of Medford has not had a city solicitor for many years.

[Scarpelli]: So that money would carry over year after year.

[Scarpelli]: Every year a salary from the city solicitor includes annual budget, because no one is receiving the salary.

[Scarpelli]: The amounts of that, if we put aside, city solicitor's salary goes into the city's free cash reserve for the city administration, the mayor, to use as they please if they need so.

[Scarpelli]: So how does the community use its free cash?

[Scarpelli]: Cities and towns in Massachusetts use free cash after it's certified.

[Scarpelli]: The Mass Department of Revenue is responsible for certifying free cash.

[Scarpelli]: After a city or town submits its financial information to the Department of Revenue, a community will receive its notification, the total amount of free cash, which is certified, therefore available for appropriation.

[Scarpelli]: Well, does Medford have free cash?

[Scarpelli]: Yeah, we do.

[Scarpelli]: Medford has free cash.

[Scarpelli]: As of September 10th, we were looking at a total of about $34 million.

[Scarpelli]: This is certified free cash, which means it's available to use.

[Scarpelli]: And especially in crises when you talk about underfunding a $5 million deficit in the school department, that's what that money could be used for.

[Scarpelli]: And then with the vision of financial minds working together to see if there are other avenues that we should use other than overrides, I feel it would be prudent for our community.

[Scarpelli]: So most communities, the four and 5% that's been mentioned, most communities,

[Scarpelli]: you see a two to maybe $3 million of free cash after every budget year.

[Scarpelli]: Now, you've consistently seen with this administration an absurd amount of money going into free cash because revenues were under projected.

[Scarpelli]: And maybe that's done for a reason, or maybe not.

[Scarpelli]: It's something that we would love to know with more transparency.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, this community, our community, our leadership team,

[Scarpelli]: haven't done that.

[Scarpelli]: So it leads us down a very, very slippery slope and it's dividing this community.

[Scarpelli]: So while we have the free cash and have the opportunity to not put the fear mongering into the community about teacher cuts or school issues or our children, why not use the free cash and eliminate those fears and then sit down like we talked about in the past where I was shut down by this council to look at a more, um,

[Scarpelli]: transparent, open form of participation to see where we need to do these three things.

[Scarpelli]: One understanding how the city got to this financial situation to

[Scarpelli]: How are we going to fix it?

[Scarpelli]: And three, what are we doing never to see this ever again?

[Scarpelli]: And this council and this mayor and this administration haven't done that.

[Scarpelli]: That was what they came out with.

[Scarpelli]: No answer.

[Scarpelli]: That's fine.

[Scarpelli]: But this is all true.

[Scarpelli]: This is all on tape.

[Scarpelli]: So, typical fashion, Friday we get emails from the mayor's office with $7.5 million.

[Scarpelli]: Tuesday we come to a meeting, we're gonna vote on it.

[Scarpelli]: As a responsible city councilor, I will now invoke our Rule 21, close the meeting, and ask for an open meeting with everybody to talk about this in more depth.

[Scarpelli]: Something that's unheard of, has never been heard of, never been done before, but our council leadership suspends the rules of the meeting and imposes a vote to not invoke Rule 21.

[Scarpelli]: Done, you can't talk about it.

[Scarpelli]: But I will tell you, the council had five subcommittee meetings to talk about a city council newsletter.

[Scarpelli]: Five.

[Scarpelli]: And guess what that, that's free, nothing.

[Scarpelli]: But, the paper's adding up to $7.5 million and possibly more.

[Scarpelli]: They don't wanna talk about it.

[Scarpelli]: So, what do we do?

[Scarpelli]: We move on to the next meeting and I said, okay.

[Scarpelli]: I reach out to my state representative and I asked him, what is the plan?

[Scarpelli]: What can I do?

[Scarpelli]: And they said, okay.

[Scarpelli]: Legal from the state said you can now invoke Mass General Law 43, section 22.

[Scarpelli]: That supersedes any method rule, shuts the meeting down.

[Scarpelli]: Well, we get to the next meeting.

[Scarpelli]: Our leadership team does the same exact thing.

[Scarpelli]: Suspends the rules.

[Scarpelli]: Imposed, says they cannot impose rule 21.

[Scarpelli]: I then invoke section 22.

[Scarpelli]: Council leadership says, no, you can't do that.

[Scarpelli]: Against the rule, against the law.

[Scarpelli]: Because what was gonna be said is this.

[Scarpelli]: And listen closely, because this is how real communities do it.

[Scarpelli]: In 2009, working in the city of Somerville, Mayor Joe Curtatone was at a crossroads with his community.

[Scarpelli]: Big cuts looming.

[Scarpelli]: He convenes a group, a working group, a financial working group that consisted of financial minds from Tufts, MIT, Harvard, banking leaders.

[Scarpelli]: You had the Sloans from Century Bank.

[Scarpelli]: You had his financial team present.

[Scarpelli]: You had community leaders and business leaders all in a row.

[Scarpelli]: And they worked on a plan because they said you needed to figure out three things before you wanted to go to an override.

[Scarpelli]: One, how do we get there?

[Scarpelli]: We still don't know how we got here.

[Scarpelli]: At least publicly, there's nothing been mentioned.

[Scarpelli]: Two, how do we fix it?

[Scarpelli]: Three, how does this never happen again?

[Scarpelli]: That's what we were taught.

[Scarpelli]: Well, they came out and they said, okay, this is what we're going to do.

[Scarpelli]: We're going to look at traffic and parking fees.

[Scarpelli]: Not going to make people happy, but they're going to take that money.

[Scarpelli]: They're going to increase those fees.

[Scarpelli]: They're going to take that money, and that's going to be dedicated solely to the school department.

[Scarpelli]: Boom.

[Scarpelli]: Need taken away.

[Scarpelli]: Figure it out, because if you go on these different websites and you look at what override means, so let's say the MTA, they have a great blueprint.

[Scarpelli]: And they said, before you go out to do an override, you make sure you get the buy-in from stakeholders.

[Scarpelli]: We did nothing of that.

[Scarpelli]: So what I'm begging this council to do

[Scarpelli]: Like again, I'm gonna say it again, in every community that I've researched, and I've done a lot of research on this now, the three most important pieces when you talk about overrides, how did we get there?

[Scarpelli]: How are we going to correct it?

[Scarpelli]: And what are we going to do so we never have to go there again?

[Scarpelli]: We don't know how we got here.

[Scarpelli]: We're all about making sure that we want to keep residents in their homes and we're going to fight for them.

[Scarpelli]: So it's important that they come and they hear, they get the answers that we need.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Councilor Bears and Councilor Caraviello.

[Scarpelli]: I think that my frustration is what's felt throughout the community.

[Scarpelli]: You said something very important because what bothered me more than anything in this time in our country, you want people to get involved.

[Scarpelli]: And I had five to six people call me and say, you know what?

[Scarpelli]: I'll never, ever vote.

[Scarpelli]: in an election for the city ever again.

[Scarpelli]: I'll leave my vote just the national agenda and that's it.

[Scarpelli]: Because that's how disgusted they are.

[Scarpelli]: And I can see why, being part of it.

[Scarpelli]: This is, and I'll give you an example.

[Scarpelli]: Councilor Caraviello did, in running his election.

[Scarpelli]: He was honest, he was fair, he worked hard, and he asked volunteers to come out.

[Scarpelli]: And those volunteers came out to assist, like any candidate could.

[Scarpelli]: Any candidate could have done what Councilor Caraviello did.

[Scarpelli]: Now, it didn't come out in his favor, and that's life.

[Scarpelli]: But to hear the horrific issues that poll workers were put in, and the poll watchers, so people don't know,

[Scarpelli]: you're allowed to have poll watchers, and it's a machine.

[Scarpelli]: So the poll watchers go out.

[Scarpelli]: It's a calculated strategy where they're allowed to have poll watchers sit in a relatively close area that you can hear and see the process.

[Scarpelli]: The process is very simple, that the poll watchers

[Scarpelli]: There was talk that they were told they can't sit down.

[Scarpelli]: Then they were told they can't sit down if they bring their own seats.

[Scarpelli]: And if that's the case, OK, bring your own seat.

[Scarpelli]: Pole watchers sat in their seats.

[Scarpelli]: And then they were told to move 25 feet away.

[Scarpelli]: And then the process was very simple.

[Scarpelli]: The process that by law states, in the general laws that we had attorneys pass out to each polling station, each warden, and it said straight out, the process is such, when the person approaches to vote, if they have a license or not,

[Scarpelli]: because we had the new scanning system.

[Scarpelli]: And believe me, I do not blame the poll, the workers that are at the poll, I don't blame them, because a lot of them are great people and they just weren't prepared, but they had the licenses.

[Scarpelli]: They have the license, you're supposed to sweep their name and address.

[Scarpelli]: They're supposed to say, George Scarpelli, 27 Butler Street, and the poll worker responds back, George Scarpelli, correct.

[Scarpelli]: for the purpose of clarity and transparency.

[Scarpelli]: And then what they do is that person has a book, same as the workers do, and they check off who comes in and votes.

[Scarpelli]: And then if you have a machine that works for you, volunteers that want to work for you, you then have people pick up those books every two to four hours.

[Scarpelli]: And then you have people in offices or at homes calling people and saying, hey, we see you haven't voted today.

[Scarpelli]: Do you need a ride?

[Scarpelli]: It's a machine.

[Scarpelli]: It's done all over the country.

[Scarpelli]: What we saw this past Tuesday, I'm not even gonna bring up a formal, maybe I will, because I said what happened before, I said, please, this is why this country is such a mess.

[Scarpelli]: Conspiracy theories through the roof, and I'm not a conspiracy theorist, I hate it.

[Scarpelli]: And what happened this past week and the weeks before this and understanding how this process went was a disgrace.

[Scarpelli]: How much money did we lose?

[Scarpelli]: When you don't open up the boxes of the ballots to a few days before you have to mail out the mailing ballots, and you realize you have someone's name spelt wrong, so they have to be thrown away.

[Scarpelli]: Now you have to get ballots reprinted and rushed in, which is thousands of dollars.

[Scarpelli]: And then they go out and then we realize that we're getting phone calls from Ward 6 saying everybody that ordered, that requested four ballots got eight.

[Scarpelli]: Everybody that got asked for two got four.

[Scarpelli]: Everybody asked for three got six.

[Scarpelli]: And then we had to reassure the public that even though it looks bad, they cannot vote three to six times.

[Scarpelli]: And we said that day,

[Scarpelli]: that meeting before the election, please.

[Scarpelli]: If it's because you're understaffed, ask for help.

[Scarpelli]: If we have to approve anything from this council to assist, bring in a thousand people from the state, whoever you need to assist.

[Scarpelli]: Now, Councilor Caballero's team was very proactive.

[Scarpelli]: I know for sure, because my wife was one of the poll watchers, that at her location, she showed up at seven where polls open, correct?

[Scarpelli]: Well, at 7.30, they still weren't ready to go.

[Scarpelli]: Then we heard some places that we had machines that weren't working.

[Scarpelli]: By law, when you test a machine, the notice has to go out to the public and it has to be done in an open process.

[Scarpelli]: Before the election, that process has to be open to the public.

[Scarpelli]: They come in and you can watch the Elections Commission test the machines.

[Scarpelli]: That didn't happen.

[Scarpelli]: That didn't happen.

[Scarpelli]: And then as you went through the whole process, we will tell you that we were given a notice from the election director that said, the votes that were taken, the votes that were taken from early voting and absentee voting will be put through the voting machine here at City Hall at 8.30 in the morning and then posted at eight o'clock here at City Hall.

[Scarpelli]: That's a memo

[Scarpelli]: that's public that went out to the election officials, elected officials.

[Scarpelli]: And then you realize, now you go through the numbers.

[Scarpelli]: You sit there and you go through the numbers, you have people getting their numbers, and it's a mess.

[Scarpelli]: There was talks that people coming back saying that the police were being yelled at by wardens, that ballots were being counted, they didn't understand where the ballots were.

[Scarpelli]: We had people here counting ballots without being in public.

[Scarpelli]: Now that's, that's, it's, it's not to, it's, it's, it's, is it, does it affect the election?

[Scarpelli]: No, I don't think it affects the election, but the perception of it is terrible.

[Scarpelli]: And if this happens in any other, any other department, things have to be taken swiftly and quickly and making sure this doesn't happen again.

[Scarpelli]: So

[Scarpelli]: I'm gonna ask for, if we can, as a resolution, I would amend the existing paper to ask for our election commissioner, our election director, our commission,

[Scarpelli]: to come before this council to explain in detail what happened.

[Scarpelli]: And one of the biggest questions I have from a lot of people that were waiting that night at 835, we had probably between, I believe it was 10,500 votes.

[Scarpelli]: And they said, that's it.

[Scarpelli]: And we said, wait a second, Medford has never, never been that low.

[Scarpelli]: What happened to the ballots that were counted in the morning?

[Scarpelli]: We don't know what you're talking about.

[Scarpelli]: So then all of a sudden at one o'clock in the morning, they posted something that said they found the ballots and it was 4,000 more ballots and this is what it was.

[Scarpelli]: Regardless who won, who lost,

[Scarpelli]: That just doesn't look good.

[Scarpelli]: Perception is reality.

[Scarpelli]: And this is what, this is the type of situation that brings the fire to the ignorance of our country sometimes.

[Scarpelli]: And that's what's sad about this.

[Scarpelli]: So the reason for this, the reason why I want to move forward and, and get a detailed report, and then ask for, you know, the Secretary of State's office to get involved to them do an audit, because we need answers.

[Scarpelli]: So people can understand that your elected officials are holding people accountable when they're not doing their job.

[Scarpelli]: So we can squash

[Scarpelli]: and move forward for our next elections without any other issues or concerns.

[Scarpelli]: Because like Councilor Behr said, perception is reality.

[Scarpelli]: I said it the night, the week before the election.

[Scarpelli]: Perception is reality.

[Scarpelli]: And what happened is exactly what we would hope, we were scared would happen.

[Scarpelli]: Now you have a room full of people that are just as upset because the process was terrible.

[Scarpelli]: It was terrible and somebody has to be held accountable, period.

[Scarpelli]: Because in my position, if I left a little kid in the park by himself unattended, guess what?

[Scarpelli]: The next morning, I wouldn't be working.

[Scarpelli]: So in the elections department, when you make these many mistakes, something has to be done.

[Scarpelli]: So Madam President, that's my resolution.

[Scarpelli]: I appreciate it and thank you.

[Scarpelli]: I think we are at the point where everybody really expressed the same thing.

[Scarpelli]: So I think the governing body in the state needs to get involved, and I think that this council should send a letter to the Secretary of State's office, to Galvin's office, so I'd make that a formal motion that we craft a letter, send it to the Secretary of State's office, and ask them to look into this process.

[Scarpelli]: Please.

[Scarpelli]: And just if I can, Madam President, I don't want people to understand that when we heard all these issues, the poll workers that are there are maybe mostly the sweetest people in the world.

[Scarpelli]: They're doing something that's thankless, truly is thankless.

[Scarpelli]: But one thing that was resounding throughout that day is how they weren't trained properly.

[Scarpelli]: They didn't know what was right.

[Scarpelli]: And the sweetest woman that I love dearly, when I went to vote, she looked at me and she said, the first three letters of your name.

[Scarpelli]: And I said, no, that's not how it goes.

[Scarpelli]: But these are the issues that went on everywhere.

[Scarpelli]: We had one poll watcher that was put 25 feet away in the corner, was presented the law.

[Scarpelli]: She was then moved by the warden behind eight feet away in compliance.

[Scarpelli]: And then our elections commissioner came in and said, get out, go back to where you were.

[Scarpelli]: That's not the rule.

[Scarpelli]: And we stopped that completely.

[Scarpelli]: We ended up moving with the city and Oasis, we ended up bringing in planters, gigantic planters, so they couldn't park up on the curb.

[Scarpelli]: that we're paying them hundreds and hundreds of dollars just by picking up the phone.

[Scarpelli]: I hate that we have to ask them, but because we don't have a city attorney in the city for a year, I think with this situation, I think it's warranted because either way, I don't wanna make a decision either favoring or being against without knowing the true ramifications legally.

[Scarpelli]: So I hope you can understand that.

[Scarpelli]: the city and really one department to make a decision what's greater for our community without the true input of what the community wants and the visions of what they see.

[Scarpelli]: We've been screaming this for years.

[Scarpelli]: truly, I can't support this for the fact that we've been asking for a true comprehensive plan of what we want to do as a community, what direction we want to go in.

[Scarpelli]: It's come to my attention that

[Scarpelli]: our turf fields are in disarray.

[Scarpelli]: And although we appreciate all the hard work going into all of these grant funded parks and playgrounds, I think our city administration has forgotten about the existing fields.

[Scarpelli]: And this is something that I've been putting on the agenda for years, hoping someone would listen.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, when I'm gathering from some parents, they're a little nervous, especially what's happening in Medford High School.

[Scarpelli]: The field is a turf field.

[Scarpelli]: The field does have black pellets, but the field hasn't been tested for GMAX.

[Scarpelli]: Now what the GMAX study does is it should be tested every year, this is what we do in my profession, on a turf and natural surface fields to make sure the density is safe after a long period of time.

[Scarpelli]: The Field of Dreams was started back in early 2010.

[Scarpelli]: We're now coming on to 2024, and the life expectancy of a turf field that is maintained properly, that means to come in and groom it on a regular basis, that means on a yearly basis, coming in and doing a deep clean, that means taking the pellets up,

[Scarpelli]: re-grooming the surface and then re-entering the pellets, which, from what I gather, we haven't done on a consistent basis here in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: What was brought to my attention, the way I brought this up, is that as soon as someone says safety to me, I have to present it in a resolution so the city can get back to us in a timeline that

[Scarpelli]: God forbid somebody gets hurt and those tests weren't done, then the liability, and if the attorney's still here, this would be great because I know if the city solicitor were here, I know that that would be something very important to stress the fact that getting that test done.

[Scarpelli]: Again, what I request is the city administration to have a licensed turf

[Scarpelli]: contractor come in with a GMAC study for turf, not natural surface.

[Scarpelli]: They're two different tests.

[Scarpelli]: And they do a test at Edgley Fields behind the high school, the fields at Hormel Stadium, and from what I gather, the field at the Brooks School is absolutely deplorable.

[Scarpelli]: It's probably one of the most used playgrounds in the community.

[Scarpelli]: I know our school age kids at the Brooks love that field considering what they had years ago and the mud bowl that they used to have to and then bring it into the school and it started destroying the floors at the school.

[Scarpelli]: The community really put a good effort, but they forgot again.

[Scarpelli]: an existing playground and park and Metro completely forgotten.

[Scarpelli]: to those fields, it's simple as this.

[Scarpelli]: natural surface fields have to have a resting period.

[Scarpelli]: And it really hurts our bottom line when it comes to road work in our community.

[Scarpelli]: So if you talk to most people that own homes on private ways, they have a lot of pride and they maintain their homes.

[Scarpelli]: And they talked to these professionals and said, because this isn't a major way, you should use this type of top, this type of patch.

[Scarpelli]: The city diverted all of the traffic where?

[Scarpelli]: But again, when you're not talking, you're not communicating with your residents, this is a huge concern.

[Scarpelli]: So these are the things that are open-ended.

[Scarpelli]: And this is what we're putting office we're putting office to be their voice.

[Scarpelli]: And that's not an easy place to stand, but when you were elected or you're hired in a municipal field, that's part of your job.

[Scarpelli]: That's your, that's part of your job requirements.

[Scarpelli]: Come here and answer these questions so residents can understand what the process is.

[Scarpelli]: I think we need more communication through the administration to really let our constituents know of these processes.

[Scarpelli]: When no one comes up to answer these questions, everything's left open-ended.

[Scarpelli]: And the frustration gets to a boiling point where we're seeing good people in this community putting for sale signs and moving out.

[Scarpelli]: And that I hate to see.

[Scarpelli]: And all it is sometimes is just simple conversation.

[Scarpelli]: You saw what we did tonight with a very, very, very

[Scarpelli]: productive business in our city and neighbors that had an issue.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Madam President, I think that the goal for this is really to educate the constituents, and

[Scarpelli]: And so I would like to see a community hall with those residents of private ways, get the word out.

[Scarpelli]: And I appreciate Councilor Knight and Councilor Bears sending that information, but when you are living to a certain standard here, and you've grown up in a private way or lived in a private way, and all of a sudden snap a finger, the way that you've lived your life, things have changed now, whether it's right, wrong or indifferent.

[Scarpelli]: The residents that live in those private ways have to be reeducated and really have to acknowledge what needs to be expected as they move on.

[Scarpelli]: If this is the way it goes, like Councilor Knight said,

[Scarpelli]: the I don't blame the city engineer in any way.

[Scarpelli]: I question his his behavior or his tone with what residents have told me.

[Scarpelli]: And you know, I'd like I said, if he was here, I'd love to ask him but but that's the what I question with our our city engineer.

[Scarpelli]: Again, my question is really

[Scarpelli]: you're making changes, sweeping changes that are really affecting our community.

[Scarpelli]: And especially when it comes to public safety, when people are expecting their sidewalks to get done.

[Scarpelli]: Because imagine if, like Councilor Knight said, you have a sidewalk that's panels lifted, you have an elderly parent that lives in your home with you.

[Scarpelli]: You're expecting the city to make these changes because they've been on this list, so they wait.

[Scarpelli]: Now all of a sudden they're told that after three years you're top of that list.

[Scarpelli]: They know we're not fixing it because you're a private way.

[Scarpelli]: We're changing our policy.

[Scarpelli]: So that's the process.

[Scarpelli]: I think we need to meet with all of these departments and really set the tone with how to reeducate our private way residents.

[Scarpelli]: And then maybe they have to answer some questions about legitimate questions that were brought about on detours and sending heavy trucking that ruined a street that has just been paved.

[Scarpelli]: So these are legitimate issues.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello for bringing this up.

[Scarpelli]: Uh, Mr. Howard wasn't just a gentleman who

[Scarpelli]: who created an infamous breakfast sandwich.

[Scarpelli]: He's someone that fought for our country, that loved Medford, and someone that really cared about his community.

[Scarpelli]: Living up in the heights and working on the board of Little League, we'd find ourselves as parents preparing a field at 95 degrees, and without field, Mr. Howard would be walking toward you with two gallons of water just to make sure that we're hydrated.

[Scarpelli]: They'll show up one day and drop off a bucket of balls that people didn't collect and make sure the kids got back went back to the kids.

[Scarpelli]: I love the story back in the blizzard of 78, when no one can leave their houses, and you had elderly families that couldn't find.

[Scarpelli]: a gallon of milk or half a loaf of bread, and Mr. Howard decided to ration off everything in his corner store to make sure everybody lasted through that difficult time in 78.

[Scarpelli]: I send deep condolences to the Howard family.

[Scarpelli]: I know Mrs. Howard is represented by a name on the corner of Fulton Street.

[Scarpelli]: I ask the administration to, with respect, add Mr. Howard's name along with his wife in respect of that historical corner that I think everybody should drive by, walk by,

[Scarpelli]: ride your bike by, look up and say, wow, I wonder who that person was.

[Scarpelli]: And you can know about what it means to be a true community member and what it really means to be a Medford Mustang.

[Scarpelli]: Because again, I've said it too many times here, who's gonna take their place?

[Scarpelli]: People like Mr. Howard stepping, passing on, who's gonna take their place to pass on the legacies that great people from Metro made up.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: And maybe from time to time, the rumors that he might have jumped over the rail a couple times.

[Scarpelli]: but he had so much passion to make sure that the city of Medford was represented in such a positive light.

[Scarpelli]: In the past,

[Scarpelli]: With the explicit permission of the school department and buildings principal, school parking has been made available for use by individual Medford residents, other city departments, including the Department of Public Works and Public Safety Department, public and private contractors for temporary parking of construction machinery and other entities and organizations, including film crews working in the city of Medford.

[Scarpelli]: the school parking space will not in any way impede or interfere with student employee or public access to school facilities.

[Scarpelli]: We are now putting in a policy in the middle of the summer that will now open up all the coaching positions and the athletic director, the big question was the athletic directors were not involved in the hiring, that the process is skewed and this is, you know, witch hunts.

[Scarpelli]: And that's where we've got some phone calls that during the fall season, the fall season starts in a few weeks.

[Scarpelli]: And the process is in place right now to

[Scarpelli]: have a committee put together.

[Scarpelli]: And the rumor was that it was gonna be just parents and kids hiring coaches, not true.

[Scarpelli]: The superintendent and I shared what we do in neighbor community where I'm part of that as a former coach, I'm also involved in the hiring team.

[Scarpelli]: That's between six to eight individuals.

[Scarpelli]: It's not two or three people.

[Scarpelli]: It's not people that are on there that don't like a coach that's sitting in the position right now.

[Scarpelli]: It's a position where we have the athletic directors, the assistant assistant athletic director, the the athletic trainer, you have two sitting seniors or captains that are coming back that season, and alumni that played that sport.

[Scarpelli]: You also have a parent and you have either a teacher in the school or a coach that's in the system.

[Scarpelli]: And so it's a whole, it's a whole committee.

[Scarpelli]: It's a true committee.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that, um, you know, that's, that's what we do.

[Scarpelli]: It's, it's very important that every school in the greater Boston league does that.

[Scarpelli]: I know that I talked to, uh, athletic director Maloney, he met with the superintendent.

[Scarpelli]: They had a great discussion when I was told that the process is exactly what, what I just said, that that's the hope.

[Scarpelli]: So again, let's, let's, you know, not jump ahead of it, not,

[Scarpelli]: it, you know, because kids are nervous, and I expressed the superintendent in this way, because of the fall season is what I'm a little concerned about.

[Scarpelli]: By the time the committee's put together, by the time the interviews are done, you're looking probably the middle of August, the season starts the third week of August.

[Scarpelli]: Using football, for example, if the football coach is let go and a new coach comes in, you are giving the student athletes that have been involved with this coach the last three years.

[Scarpelli]: This is every sport, girls' soccer, boys' soccer, golf, volleyball.

[Scarpelli]: coaches that involved last two months with the student athletes working camps, giving back to the community, kids getting in shape.

[Scarpelli]: The other piece that was was brought forth is you have coaches from colleges that are talking to student athletes, and they're discussing the possibility of being recruited and

[Scarpelli]: to make a coaching change this quick might be detrimental for their future.

[Scarpelli]: So the superintendent understood, we agreed to disagree.

[Scarpelli]: But I think that, you know, I think the process in place is a fair and open process.

[Scarpelli]: It's just like, like she said, it's an anomaly, because you have to start somehow, you have to start sometime.

[Scarpelli]: So my wish was starting for the winter season, if this is a process we move to.

[Scarpelli]: But again, I think the answer is very simple.

[Scarpelli]: It's not

[Scarpelli]: The athletic director is involved.

[Scarpelli]: It's a true committee, from what I was told by the superintendent, of a varied amount of people.

[Scarpelli]: It's not just two people, a parent that doesn't like a coach, or a kid that doesn't like a coach.

[Scarpelli]: So I appreciate letting me discuss.

[Scarpelli]: I think publicly it needed to be said, because I don't think there's a forum, as we get closer to the season, that I think the kids wanted me to give an answer.

[Scarpelli]: Their parents had reached out.

[Scarpelli]: I appreciate it, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: As a first-generation U.S.

[Scarpelli]: resident and Method resident, I was born to Italian-born parents who grew up in northern Italy in two little towns in Calabria.

[Scarpelli]: And they came to this country, the greatest country in the world, to make something of themselves and for their families and start

[Scarpelli]: the legacy that they would be proud of.

[Scarpelli]: They came to this community and they loved Medford and appreciate Councilor Knight, excuse me, Councilor Caraviello for speaking earlier, but you have to understand there's still so many Italian Americans in Medford that were raised like me and have parents like mine and the sacrifices they made and to be just part of that

[Scarpelli]: that history and that pride of being an American citizen.

[Scarpelli]: It's funny, my dad, while my mother raised, well, she parented four children on her own, while my dad worked as a member of Revere Sugar, he worked at a meat packing company and at glass cutting.

[Scarpelli]: company while going to Don Bosco High School to learn English because, as he said it, it was his honor to learn the language of the great country he moved to.

[Scarpelli]: And I think that stands for a lot of Italian-Americans, proud Italian-Americans that live in Medford today.

[Scarpelli]: And just to acknowledge that fact that this is a good time to mention what they've done to make Medford what it is today, whether it's the arts, whether it's education, whether it's, you know, in the, you know,

[Scarpelli]: the political field.

[Scarpelli]: We have Italian Americans, greatness all over this community.

[Scarpelli]: four, five, six, 10 similar locations, all the way down Mystic Ave, where there's establishments to eat, go for a drink, go for shopping, to live.

[Scarpelli]: That building is beautiful.

[Scarpelli]: But we have a unicorn sticking out of an eight-story unicorn sticking out of probably the most densely populated traffic area that we've had so many issues in the past.

[Scarpelli]: Some tragic news.

[Scarpelli]: Again, when Chris brings up

[Scarpelli]: people that have given to our community.

[Scarpelli]: There's a gentleman who kids grew up in Medford, coached his youngest son, watched Freddy Rita give back to the kids in the community.

[Scarpelli]: And when people weren't supposed to give to this much time and effort for certain type of kids,

[Scarpelli]: Freddie would go and find the kids that couldn't afford a pair of cleats, or a pair of shin guards.

[Scarpelli]: And he would make sure that he would buy those cleats and buy those shin guards, and then he'd put them on a team.

[Scarpelli]: And then when at the time there was, you know, this infighting with method you soccer, and some people thought that kids in need really weren't

[Scarpelli]: getting the attention they deserve, Freddie and some others, dedicated members of the community, decided to start a new league called Method United.

[Scarpelli]: And they did that, not because of ego, but to make sure every kid was represented.

[Scarpelli]: And it worked.

[Scarpelli]: And what happened after a few years, that group then became, came together again as a true Method youth soccer organization that we see today.

[Scarpelli]: A true vision of what the demographic of what Method truly looks like.

[Scarpelli]: The canvas that is Medford.

[Scarpelli]: And Freddie's love for the game of soccer and Freddie's passion to help kids was evident.

[Scarpelli]: Freddie's a great story because I saw him a few weeks ago at a baseball game and we were talking and I didn't realize Freddie was an orphan.

[Scarpelli]: And I said, there's no way that an orphan has the ability to raise such an amazing family.

[Scarpelli]: And that's what he did.

[Scarpelli]: He raised amazing children and

[Scarpelli]: His wife, Adele, is just one of the best people that I've ever met.

[Scarpelli]: And unfortunately, Freddy lost his life mowing his lawn.

[Scarpelli]: And it's something that I know my family, myself, we're gonna miss Freddy.

[Scarpelli]: He was very special.

[Scarpelli]: And we send our condolences to his family.

[Scarpelli]: He was one of the great ones.

[Scarpelli]: Well, people calling me saying, well, where is that going to now lead the people?

[Scarpelli]: They're going to lead them right into their right turns into their neighborhoods.

[Scarpelli]: other situations.

[Scarpelli]: And we're not seeing that.

[Scarpelli]: they pull into bike lanes, they block driveways, and they do whatever, they are now dictating what happens on our streets.

[Scarpelli]: I know I've received multiple phone calls, especially Ward 6, that we did get an email from the chief of staff, and I'll read that if that's okay, Madam President.

[Scarpelli]: Dear President Morell and city councilors, we recently learned that some addresses who are requesting early voting ballots have received more than one ballot.

[Scarpelli]: A short while ago, Steve Smerti and I met with elections to better understand what happened.

[Scarpelli]: Well, the uh...

[Scarpelli]: Well, this process is not, it happened, there's still checks and balances that are in the system.

[Scarpelli]: I'm sorry, my email is breaking up.

[Scarpelli]: In the system that would prevent someone from being able to physically cast multiple ballots.

[Scarpelli]: So there are fail-safes to make sure that you cannot vote twice.

[Scarpelli]: Specifically, there is a unique identifier assigned to each voter and only allows them to cast a ballot once.

[Scarpelli]: As we learn more about how this happened and steps that are going to be taken to avoid this from reoccurring, we will update the council.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that what I appreciate going forward with this resolution is the first thing is just to express that multiple phone calls that are very, very concerned with voter fraud, right?

[Scarpelli]: And the conspiracy theorists are going crazy.

[Scarpelli]: we bring the developers in to get their idea first.

[Scarpelli]: Not somewhere that you have to find one, you have to find where this meeting is and then go out and look for it and then not have the proper people in that can answer the questions.

[Scarpelli]: But neighboring communities, what they do is they bring everybody in.

[Scarpelli]: So every question is answered right there.

[Scarpelli]: So then we could set up a comprehensive plan that involves all the stakeholders.

[Scarpelli]: Now, that means that not everybody's gonna be happy with some of the decisions.

[Scarpelli]: but at least they can look at outcomes.

[Scarpelli]: So part of the deal was that we would have a shuttle system in place that would be built in with the developers that we don't need senior citizens who didn't need the parking in that area for it was identified for a small group, I think it was 50 people.

[Scarpelli]: So they looked at how they would shuttle the seniors in, and that was part of the contract.

[Scarpelli]: So that's being creative.

[Scarpelli]: And again, that's at least giving you an option to give you calm and understand that people are looking out for you.

[Scarpelli]: Because a friend that came up to the podium said that our seniors are afraid that we're being forgotten.

[Scarpelli]: Yeah, I hear you.

[Scarpelli]: Because today it's in front of one person's home.

[Scarpelli]: But like we talked about, they're expecting another 40, 50 who knows how many more

[Scarpelli]: So this scares a lot of people.

[Scarpelli]: There are a lot of questions out there.

[Scarpelli]: And I'll tell you, it just tells you how great the city of Medford is.

[Scarpelli]: I heard some great dialogue from some brilliant people in our community.

[Scarpelli]: Unfortunately, the only people that were answering those questions were scientists, or managers, or people involved with Verizon.

[Scarpelli]: Either they work for the construction companies that'll be doing the installation, they weren't directly, one of the questions, do you work with Verizon?

[Scarpelli]: And the answer was, no, I work for this company.

[Scarpelli]: Well, that's the company that puts in the towers for Verizon.

[Scarpelli]: So technically, he's telling the truth.

[Scarpelli]: But these are the issues that we have.

[Scarpelli]: And why do we know that when communication can either help or hurt, with the lack of?

[Scarpelli]: A few years back, a gentleman named Bill Carr Jr.

[Scarpelli]: started a committee to build new fields behind Medford High School.

[Scarpelli]: And what he did was he went out and secured a cell phone tower of over a million dollars to pay for those fields.

[Scarpelli]: And he was given every single hurdle to jump over, every single route to run through.

[Scarpelli]: And one of the biggest questions those neighbors had in the area, because everybody knows around the Medford High School area, there's absolutely zero cell space there, that no one can pick up a call.

[Scarpelli]: And that's one of the number one cell areas in the country, we were told.

[Scarpelli]: And what we did is we brought in

[Scarpelli]: Educators and scientists from MIT and Tufts that we didn't pay, they came in on their own, brought in by the community members because they worked at MIT or worked at Tufts, and they brought these professionals in that really helped all the neighbors understand what the scenarios were.

[Scarpelli]: And that, to be honest with you, it calmed a lot of people down.

[Scarpelli]: What we're seeing right now, what I'm hearing now with hundreds of emails and phone calls is the lack of representation of an independent person, an independent scientist that are gonna give us a little more insight.

[Scarpelli]: Instead, we heard some great dialogue from people that have done their homework.

[Scarpelli]: I know one gentleman, he had the study from Europe that they don't allow this at all.

[Scarpelli]: It's not even a question.

[Scarpelli]: So, you know, the Board of Health was a member of that committee who voted no, that should speak volumes.

[Scarpelli]: So again, I implore the city administrators that will be running this meeting, whatever department it is, whether it's Alicia Hunt, whether it's Tim McGivern, that they do not stop the process of our residents being able to speak, because this is their forum.

[Scarpelli]: This is their community.

[Scarpelli]: And I will tell you, if that does happen Thursday night, I will do everything in my power to make sure they are punished in every way possible through the state.

[Scarpelli]: So again, Councilor Marks, I will not try to delve into what you've already said.

[Scarpelli]: I think that it was stated perfectly, and I appreciate you standing strong, and I agree.

[Scarpelli]: We're gonna sue our own entity here in the city.

[Scarpelli]: I'm not afraid to stand up and make sure that our citizens are safe.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you very much.

[Scarpelli]: Nice job.

[Scarpelli]: issues with the census is making sure that Medford gets as due when it comes to funding from the federal government for education, police, fire, and so on.

[Scarpelli]: that we get an idea of what our plan for our city administration is to get the word out.

[Scarpelli]: Mr. President.

[Scarpelli]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Scarpelli]: First, I'd like to thank, I know there's a group of residents that are actively taking a role in making sure that this is presented the right way so it's sent to the state in the most positive light moving forward.

[Scarpelli]: When I was first elected, one of my first

[Scarpelli]: one of my first initiatives was looking at the charter view and making sure that we could revisit something that we haven't seen in so many years.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that had changed with me last time we voted, I voted no.

[Scarpelli]: And the reasons were very simple.

[Scarpelli]: It was so simple that what was asked for was yes or no and move forward.

[Scarpelli]: I think it's important that as you talk about a commission,

[Scarpelli]: One of the biggest things I think needs some debate is the understanding of ward and precinct representation.

[Scarpelli]: I think that sounds so easy for everybody and there are definitely some pros in that aspect of making sure that each ward are represented.

[Scarpelli]: speaking for myself, working in a municipality in a community that has ward and precinct representation, I see a lot of negative affects of that situation where it becomes a special interest option, special interest groups around the city.

[Scarpelli]: What I see is a lot of negativity in the sense that you have one community member and one part of the community holding

[Scarpelli]: their colleagues hostage in for what they want their initiatives to move forward not what's greater for their community as a whole, but for their small piece of the community and you could, I saw negative effects, a few times that.

[Scarpelli]: It didn't, it didn't help the community, and, and that's because of that and you know some other options that when you know you get a phone call from someone from South Medford or get a phone call from someone from West Medford or someone from the Walton Glenwood area.

[Scarpelli]: I work just as hard as if it was someone in my own backyard.

[Scarpelli]: So it gives people the opportunities to call seven different Councilors to really push an initiative, or a concern that they're not following so I see the benefits there I know that there are benefits to go through with it to look at that but again,

[Scarpelli]: when it was first presented as charter change or charter review, it was cut and dry.

[Scarpelli]: I had a great discussion with some members of the committee and talking about having a forum where we could discuss these options, where it's more of a thought process that it's discussed, it's understood, and maybe moving forward, it could be something that as you go forward with the initiative,

[Scarpelli]: and what you're looking for for charter review, at least.

[Scarpelli]: every piece is broken down and discussed and then thought upon.

[Scarpelli]: So, but I do think these, as we move forward with this initiative, I think that I would support it now.

[Scarpelli]: I would move forward, I think, but it's also a lot of questions that I think that we should really meet together with the administration and the committee members that are looking to form this commission.

[Scarpelli]: So, okay.

[Scarpelli]: So that's one thing I wanted to make sure that everybody knows.

[Scarpelli]: And that, again, to be clear, this is year after year that the override tax doesn't disappear.

[Scarpelli]: This just increases plus two and a half percent, if that so be it, every year to follow.

[Scarpelli]: I think that's what the questions were.

[Scarpelli]: And then the other thing that's confusing people when you talk about new growth, when you hear new growth in communities that have a booming commercial base or you're seeing a new tax revenue coming from new development,

[Scarpelli]: That's the new growth we haven't seen much in Medford.

[Scarpelli]: So I want people to understand the new growth that we've been talking about during the override, it's new growth coming from increasing taxes that we see as the levy increases.

[Scarpelli]: So I want people to understand that.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that was very important.

[Scarpelli]: That was a question that's been brought up saying that, oh no, they've heard from some councils that said that Medford was number one in Massachusetts in new growth, which isn't true.

[Scarpelli]: So I just wanted to make sure that those points were just brought up tonight.

[Scarpelli]: So it's a different new growth

[Scarpelli]: we talk about new growth and development is very different than what you talked about tonight, and new growth and tax assessment.

[Scarpelli]: So am I correct with that?

[Scarpelli]: I don't want to speak for you.

[Scarpelli]: Okay.

[Scarpelli]: And then I think that the last piece is what everybody's asking for now is what Mr. Castagnetti has been saying for years is the owner occupied.

[Scarpelli]: I know it's a slippery slope because it sounds so easy.

[Scarpelli]: So my neighbor who's 86 years old said, George, if this, if you vote in the tax exemption, I'm living a single family home.

[Scarpelli]: If I'm if the exemption goes through for homeowners and I get my taxes would be lower than what they were in the previous years.

[Scarpelli]: I said that's true, but when you look at the way we look at the big picture.

[Scarpelli]: It affects.

[Scarpelli]: majority of our residents in a negative way, correct?

[Scarpelli]: Their tax will increase even higher.

[Scarpelli]: Because the word is out that Somerville does it, Cambridge does it.

[Scarpelli]: Why is it beneficial for their communities?

[Scarpelli]: What do they have that we don't that allows them to do that?

[Scarpelli]: So typically, communities like that will adopt it.

[Scarpelli]: OK.

[Scarpelli]: I appreciate you.

[Scarpelli]: appreciate all the hard work you guys, your team has done.

[Scarpelli]: It's been, uh, I know it's been trying.

[Scarpelli]: I know that you were on the hot seat a month ago and I apologize for any, any, um, you know, um, uncomfortable questions that were asked, but I know it was, you stood there and did a wonderful job and, and, uh, we, you know, appreciate getting that out the Friday, the week before, so people can get a better understanding of what it looked like.

[Scarpelli]: So thank you so much.

[Scarpelli]: Absolutely.

[Scarpelli]: We're seeing things that, unfortunately, your department

[Scarpelli]: I've been tasked to do things way too late, right?

[Scarpelli]: They're hurting.
