[Scarpelli]: that bought their homes for $50,000, but now they're worth a million, and they're being priced out with additional override taxes.

[Scarpelli]: But again,

[Scarpelli]: So the fear now is the talk that was started last year was rent control.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that this is something that this community should really pay close attention to because there's a machine that's going.

[Scarpelli]: there's a system in place and people have to see what's happening with our council in the direction they've been moving to, whether it was, you know, transfer tax, whether it's fees for a registry, whether it's an override, whether it's a homeowner exemption now and looking at rent control possibly in the future.

[Scarpelli]: There's a lot that this city is gonna be moving to if people don't realize and get more involved.

[Scarpelli]: This administration, like my colleague said has done a, at least from what I gather, she was saying she was saying that they've done a terrible job, really preparing this community, and what avenues we can take to give us the best choices possible, both in a, a

[Scarpelli]: a speedy override discussion without the input and without the proper timing during the budget season.

[Scarpelli]: And now here we go with the assessment and the levy that we have to look at, look at homeowner exemption as we move forward.

[Scarpelli]: earlier in the season now, when we get to the budget season to make sure we have enough money in the overlay to make sure that if we have that 49.9% of homeowners that apply for the exemption, that we can cover that cost.

[Scarpelli]: we were taken off the bond rating by Moody's, one of our investment companies that give us our bond rating because of some technical issues with filing.

[Scarpelli]: I believe I was told, I'm not sure, but I think that we're here that

[Scarpelli]: They took a murder off the street that way.

[Scarpelli]: You're looking to put into action policies that take away that ability for our police and our community.

[Scarpelli]: I just think this is stepping over a line.

[Scarpelli]: This is something that, you know, we just don't do this at 12 o'clock at night.

[Scarpelli]: I know, but to do it at 12 o'clock at night and not have the process over just a subcommittee meeting where everybody wasn't privy to it and then come to here today and start moving these ordinances.

[Scarpelli]: I too talked to Rocco DiRico.

[Scarpelli]: First, I think we're very fortunate both between Barbara and Rocco and having liaisons from Tufts University that pick up the phone the minute we call them.

[Scarpelli]: So I think that's a huge benefit.

[Scarpelli]: you know, 12 stories, and how frightening that is, and Tufts even conceding to 10 stories.

[Scarpelli]: And I've seen all the concessions that Tufts made, and I've been fortunate enough to be involved with a mayor that was directly involved with Tufts University.

[Scarpelli]: And he allowed me to watch him be a partner, but make sure that

[Scarpelli]: his community was present and getting the best with that community needed.

[Scarpelli]: It's 1215, so who cares?

[Scarpelli]: and their impact of the quality of life.

[Scarpelli]: He began as the MSO's Chief Legal Counsel in March 1997, serving until 2009 of August.

[Scarpelli]: when he was appointed as Special Sheriff.

[Scarpelli]: Following the passing of the Sheriff Jimmy DePaulo in November of 2010, Special Sheriff Granara ably ran this agency until the appointment of Sheriff Katushin.

[Scarpelli]: Providing leadership at the pivotal time for the Middlesex Sheriff's Office, he was an invaluable source of knowledge, leadership, and friendship to me and many others throughout his tenure.

[Scarpelli]: It was our great privilege to have him remain as a Special Sheriff until August of 2011.

[Scarpelli]: responses over the last year as we continually struggle to effectively fund our priorities, especially our school priorities due to the cost of inflation.

[Scarpelli]: Our administration has continued the process of reviewing department overtime budgets and procedures.

[Scarpelli]: Since February 2024 especially, I've been focusing on OT even more and working with all department heads that have OT line items in their budget to make sure all public funds are being used the best way possible and to make sure there is not misuse or overuse of such funds.

[Scarpelli]: The city's obligation to fund overtime is necessary to ensure the general public's safety, fulfill contractual obligations, and for the efficient operations of our community.

[Scarpelli]: However, we must be strategic in how the staffing is deployed as the funding resources are extremely limited and there are critical needs throughout our school district and city.

[Scarpelli]: Overtime is a crucial component

[Scarpelli]: of every municipality's budget and operations.

[Scarpelli]: We need DPW crews out on the streets plowing snow, removing trees that block roadways, and other critical tasks to keep our roadways accessible and safe.

[Scarpelli]: Police and fire OT for several reasons.

[Scarpelli]: In some circumstances, we need building inspectors to be able to visit homes and make determinations on living conditions.

[Scarpelli]: But we need to manage how overtime is allocated so we don't create a situation

[Scarpelli]: where we're spending taxpayers' money unnecessarily.

[Scarpelli]: That's why we're working with the department heads to develop a policy that enables them to manage their time to their team effectively and implement the overtime procedures that meets the needs of our constituency.

[Scarpelli]: The police department has done a much better job curbing overtime and has lowered the police overtime budget from about $2 million in 2018

[Scarpelli]: to an average number of 1.2 million for the past four years, a reduction of over 35%.

[Scarpelli]: The fire chief and mayor's office, the human resources director, are working diligently on accountability as it relates to OT.

[Scarpelli]: As one example, 28 letters have been issued to staff putting them on notice that their sick time use, which causes the need for overtime, seems excessive.

[Scarpelli]: Within the DPW, we hired DPW commissioners to help manage the department, specifically the OT budget.

[Scarpelli]: The topic on the agenda is how overtime is managed in our building department.

[Scarpelli]: We cannot have a union member fielding calls and assigning overtime shifts to themselves and their fellow employees.

[Scarpelli]: That presents a conflict that we made this change over the years.

[Scarpelli]: This did find to be necessary change, especially when almost $50,000 was paid out to overtime during the period my chief of staff was out on maternity leave.

[Scarpelli]: Our current building commissioner fields the calls from dispatch as part of department responses hierarchy and works within the written protocol to determine the immediate life safety status situations in an effort to determine the need for an inspector on scene.

[Scarpelli]: If the situation does not present an urgent need to respond, the commissioner will decline to send an inspector.

[Scarpelli]: The address is tracked and scheduled for follow-up by an inspector the next day.

[Scarpelli]: In instances where our commissioner is unavailable, our former commissioner is contacted and makes a determination.

[Scarpelli]: The former commission has received less than a handful of calls over the last year and has paid $60 per call.

[Scarpelli]: The building department continues to develop protocol and the training to fine tune the best possible responses of the concerns and staff welcome construction feedback.

[Scarpelli]: Mayor Kern.

[Scarpelli]: Thank you.

[Scarpelli]: Now, what I've been hearing is nothing what was just read.

[Scarpelli]: What we're seeing right now is practice that we've seen that I believe that our building department, by law, if you indulge me, Mr. President, by law, Mass Amendments Building Codes, Section 116.1 Unsafe Structures,

[Scarpelli]: I'm hearing that we have concerns with protocol that's now been lifted because of said overtime, as the mayor has stated.

[Scarpelli]: What we're seeing right now, I don't believe is true.

[Scarpelli]: What I'm seeing right now is that our building inspectors who historically have gone out and not used the overtime that's been stated for overuse or misuse,

[Scarpelli]: but because it's standard and it's practice and it's making sure our constituents are safe.

[Scarpelli]: When a structure is put in crisis, whether it's be fire or water or some kind of accident that maybe a car hits a home and it's after hours, our inspectors are called and they're the governing body that comes in to deem that facility safe.

[Scarpelli]: What we're being told now is that we have a protocol in place where, because of financial reasons, we have, that's another question, we have the former director, the former commissioner of the building department still on staff being paid.

[Scarpelli]: It says that he's paid $60 when he's called, but I would like to know what he is paid by still being on the books.

[Scarpelli]: Because if we're hurting for money, there's a question there.

[Scarpelli]: What I've been told is that if the building department isn't called, then the fire department, the deputy on call, will make that decision.

[Scarpelli]: That is dangerous.

[Scarpelli]: They're not the governing body or the body that deems a structure safe.

[Scarpelli]: And that is a huge liability and huge safety issue and concern for our residents and our homeowners and our constituents.

[Scarpelli]: So we're seeing some very, very questionable practices.

[Scarpelli]: I find it very difficult that this mayor is putting this into place with other questionable reasons as we're moving forward, and I'll get to those later.

[Scarpelli]: But we have our fire department that is thin as it is,

[Scarpelli]: that if no building department is called for an overtime, which is minimal, by the way, to come in and clear that, there is a trickle down effect financially that harms our community even more than any overtime.

[Scarpelli]: You're asking for our firefighters to come down.

[Scarpelli]: You're asking for possible detail from the fire department to sit there possibly for four, eight hours in overtime.

[Scarpelli]: And then you're possibly leaving our community in crisis

[Scarpelli]: by the ability not to have an engine back to where it should be, where it's needed.

[Scarpelli]: Instead, it could be possibly at that site.

[Scarpelli]: This is something that I don't understand why it's happening.

[Scarpelli]: This is something that I find it very difficult to understand.

[Scarpelli]: This isn't an organization, a group of people that have worked very hard for this community for many, many years and done so much for us and really just do their job.

[Scarpelli]: And we're seeing some tactics by this mayor that it's very glaring against the working men and women of our community.

[Scarpelli]: It seems like it's very petty, and it seems like it's very vindictive.

[Scarpelli]: I've been told that our building department now has had practice on Wednesday nights, the late evening, that they would have a working dinner as a group

[Scarpelli]: with the commissioner for many years, this commissioner, the past commissioners, that they would come in and they would have dinner together.

[Scarpelli]: And that practice has stopped.

[Scarpelli]: What reason?

[Scarpelli]: We don't know.

[Scarpelli]: But for the ability to have your commissioners there, when a constituent comes in and has the ability to talk to any one of the building inspectors that they're working with on site, that's a relief.

[Scarpelli]: Now you're told that these people have to now maybe, they can leave, they can go out for the half hour.

[Scarpelli]: Now you have constituents that are accustomed to have someone there no matter what.

[Scarpelli]: Well, we have a slow turnout.

[Scarpelli]: Well, imagine if we have an award representation.

[Scarpelli]: Have we seen, maybe the Collins Center can help us.

[Scarpelli]: When you see organizations go from at large to award representations, I'm assuming that voter turnout will be larger because now,

[Scarpelli]: you have people that are identifying certain groups and certain people that will then run.

[Scarpelli]: With the ward representation being that you don't have to encompass yourself throughout the whole community, time-wise, or raise enough money to run at large, we're giving our, or even a district, we're giving our residents an opportunity to be part of this great option and be a voice.

[Scarpelli]: So I know it sounds critical and maybe I'm attacking, but

[Scarpelli]: This isn't anything that my fellow councils haven't said in meetings.

[Scarpelli]: And here I am coming back and saying, am I in a bizarro world?

[Scarpelli]: And I'll say this again.

[Scarpelli]: We're trying to pass a piece of legislation here that will go out that the city is gonna vote on.

[Scarpelli]: This is something that's popular.

[Scarpelli]: This is something that everybody I talked to on both sides, it didn't matter.

[Scarpelli]: They appreciate the ward representation.

[Scarpelli]: They appreciate that all eight wards will be represented.

[Scarpelli]: That's something they can go to the election booth in November and vote in support.

[Scarpelli]: Why would we now finally get to the finish line and try to honestly look like you're trying to control it?

[Scarpelli]: Because that's what it sounds like.

[Scarpelli]: Look, this is what it sounds like.

[Scarpelli]: It sounds like you want seven people so you can control it.

[Scarpelli]: because when you open it to 11 people, maybe you don't, you lose the majority.

[Scarpelli]: So that's the disrespect that happens time and time with this council.

[Scarpelli]: Listen, there are things that I don't, I don't like my fellow council say, but I would never disrespect and openly laugh like that.

[Scarpelli]: This is what we have.

[Scarpelli]: This is what we have at this council day after evening after evening when, when my fellow council is the chair of this meeting.

[Scarpelli]: So again,

[Scarpelli]: This isn't anything that I made up.

[Scarpelli]: I just explained what my fellow Councilors just said.

[Scarpelli]: We want this passed now.

[Scarpelli]: And I've had that open mind.

[Scarpelli]: It's allowed me to talk to a lot of people.

[Scarpelli]: And the eight wards being represented with the three out loud members is something that I would support.

[Scarpelli]: It's something that the professionals from the call center support.

[Scarpelli]: And it's what the people that have gone meeting after meeting throughout the whole community.

[Scarpelli]: Now this is being put forth by a Councilor for truly, I'll be honest with you, I don't see the weight in your presentation of why seven or district representation has been more beneficial than a true ward representation of all of our whole community.

[Scarpelli]: Mr. Chair, to my colleague that referenced the Council that got up and walked out while she was speaking, I want to apologize.

[Scarpelli]: I've been sick, so I ran out of water and I felt a little faint, so I had to go get water.

[Scarpelli]: So I apologize if I disrespected any member of the council to get water.

[Scarpelli]: So I apologize for that.

[Scarpelli]: For my colleagues that seem to be offended that I'm bringing politics into politics, sorry.

[Scarpelli]: But I don't align with you.

[Scarpelli]: You usually vote in tow, but you all vote together.

[Scarpelli]: on your agendas.

[Scarpelli]: And that's known.

[Scarpelli]: That's nothing that's a secret.

[Scarpelli]: So when I bring a topic forward, if it hurts your feelings, I'll do respect.

[Scarpelli]: I don't care.

[Scarpelli]: My goal is to make sure that everybody's view is represented.

[Scarpelli]: So I know my council colleagues are upset or feel hurt or the reason that I disrespected them.

[Scarpelli]: And this is why our community is in flux right now.

[Scarpelli]: So when we look at this situation right now,

[Scarpelli]: where we are right now, the council brought up some changes and supported it, some with facts, some with his own beliefs, his belief system, which I respect.

[Scarpelli]: what has been asked of me by constituents, maybe constituents that don't even vote for me.

[Scarpelli]: we can look back at this tape and listen to what everybody has said and what I expressed from what they said.

[Scarpelli]: This isn't made up.

[Scarpelli]: This isn't a dialogue to make this like some kind of a clown show.

[Scarpelli]: And I will not apologize for that.

[Scarpelli]: And unfortunately, my friends,

[Scarpelli]: This is politics.
